ratings.comment: I was excited for J345 with Wells but it was SO disappointing. He is SOOOOO bad with details and I honestly don't think he read the syllabus for the class. He doesn't give study guides for exams which sucks. Do not take 345 with him, I was very disappointed. The only saving grace was that my group for the campaign was awesome.

Super easy course but not curved at all.  The midterms were easy and take about 10 minutes. The discussion sections were great and super interesting. The grading wasn't super clear, the discussion activities specifically got very random grades. The lectures are good but its unnecessary to go to all the lectures. I went to a third maybe and did ok

Honestly J201 compelled me to apply to the Journalism school for a second major. The class is interesting, the expectations are clear, and the assignments aren't too difficult. That being said, there is a lot of writing in this course.

Interesting and relevant lectures with beneficial readings. There were lots of small assignments (essays, speeches, readings), but none of it was especially difficult. Probably my favorite class I took this year, and I'd definitely recommend Wells as a professor.

Chris is a fine lecturer, it's pretty easy to skip class and just learn it for the exams. Where you'll get screwed is your TA. The class isn't curved and it isn't adjusted so that all the TAs have the same average, since they do all the grading. Assignments are only worth up to 10 points so if you lose half a point on each it really ads up.

Loved his class. Easy A to be honest; material is not hard at all to understand, he's very clear on what he wants you to know, exams are straight forward and a breeze and not a lot of assignments at all. Enjoyed discussion sections; thought they were interesting and well organized. Best part though: very good looking man :)
Chris Wells is a pretty good teacher. The course material is very basic and often times the lectures are quite boring, but he can be pretty funny and the class itself is fairly straightforward.

Chris Wells is an okay professor. He expects a lot from everyone and has specific expectations. He also makes you work really hard for your grade. Just another tidbit is that he looks exactly like Lars from Heavyweights. It's hilarious!
Amazing professor. One of my favorite classes at UW so far. You actually have to work for your grade, but it's rewarding. Lecture was also always interesting.
Exams are very easy, but the semester-long group project is extremely challenging. He will help you if you seek it, but your grade is all up to you and how well your group works together.
I really enjoyed this class. Professor Wells was very clear with the information he wants students to learn.

J201 requires many reading and writing assignments, but they are interesting and not particularly difficult. The exams are a breeze if you look over the lecture slides and finish the readings. Prof. Wells made lecture enjoyable and fun. J201 was my favorite course this year.

Professor Wells is an excellent teacher and I always looked forward to going to lectures. He is organized, clear, and his tests are well written and fair. You do have to read a lot for the class, but Wells does an awesome job of finding articles that are actually relevant and interesting for students.

I loved Professor Wells. He's charismatic and really knows how to get you motivated about the subject. If you don't like to write or to read, then do not take this class. However, if you feel journalism might be the route for you, he's the best person to go to.

Just finished J201 with Chris. While he was a very nice guy, he was not a very good instructor. His lectures were meaningless and he tried to make concepts harder than they needed to be. The overall class was pretty easy though. It depends on what TA you have.

The class is horrible and Chris Wells doesn't do a good job of teaching journalism. The grading scale is horrible, some of the questions irrelevant, and he intentionally tries to make simple ideas more difficult than they actually are. It was my least favorite class of my freshman year and I would not recommend it.

J201 by Wells was a great introduction to the culture of J-School culture. 201 works like a survey course for all the possible areas of futher development at a j-schooler. Course covers very contemporary issues.  I'd say his course is a bit analytical. Papers are more or less to test your argumentive ability, rather than journalistic skill.

Chris Wells is an awesome professor. Lectures are extremely important for doing well, but are very engaging and interesting. All information is really relevant and though there is a decent amount of work, it is not too challenging. Would highly recommend this class.

Chris is a great professor. His lectures are really well organized and he uses great real life examples. It's easy to stay focused and listen to him. I always looked forward to class. The workload is definitely manageable and the TAs are very helpful. Great class, definitely recommend it as a comm B.

Wells is great and so is the class. I always looked forward to his lectures. Required readings are extremely interesting and the three essays are easy to write. Practically impossible to get below a B in this class.

Professor Wells is a great lecturer.  It is imperative to attend lecture, as there is no textbook.  Rather, Wells uses a bunch of articles as reading material.  One downfall of the course is that your TA has 100% control over your grade.  Other than that Professor Wells runs an amazing class.  The class is very interesting and tests are not hard.
J201 is a straightforward class if you keep up with reading and lectures. Decent work load but I assume that is normal for a Comm B class.

Easy class, especially for being a Comm B and Honors class (for me). Section included speeches, pop quizzes, and discussion about readings. Wells is quirky. Lecture slides are posted online but you miss a lot of the "filler" information. Definitely try to make guest lectures. Don't buy the course guide, Wells posts all the readings online.
He's kind of high on himself.  He knows what he is talking about, but he really needs to get over himself.

Chris Wells lies somewhere between awkward, sassy, and funny.  Nonetheless, he makes class interesting and is pretty clear in his lectures.  The essays are kind of daunting, but if you spend enough time on them you should do well!  Exams come from lectures and readings.  The content also is highly interesting.

I highly recommend going to lecture because the exam questions come mainly from lecture.  There are 3 essays, 2 midterms and a final.  Also, you have to attend discussion.  I highly recommend this class for anyone looking to fulfill a Com B requirement!

I honestly had such a blast with his class. I was on the fence about making journalism my major but now I'm certain about applying to the J school because of Wells. He's knowledgeable and made his lectures interesting. His last lecture of the semester was really cool, definitely thought-provoking. I also had a great TA which helped A LOT

Professor Wells is a super cool, intelligent guy, and his lectures are interesting. Not to mention, he has great taste in music. The J201 course, however, is very involved. Your grade is determined by a series of papers, tests, speeches, and quizzes, all of which are evaluated by your TA (can be a hit or a miss...mine was a miss).
Really cool guy. Plays music before class. Seems knowledgable in his field. However, the workload of this class is somewhat extreme. Your grade is almost entirely dependent on your TA as well.

Professor Wells was very knowledgeable on this this subject.  He was very good at breaking down the historical aspect of things.  At times I felt like there were random examples given, but other than that I thought all of the material was spot on.  You have a textbook, but all the articles are supplied online as well. Overall, interesting!
Hot professor! Go to lecture, do the readings, and do the study guide and a B is guaranteed. Interesting stuff so good 4 credit class!

You can tell that he's really smart and if the class didn't have to cover so much he'd be able to show off what he knows. Class is only out of 100 points so every assignment is important. Also had him for discussion and he was much better there.

Dude is awesome. He is a really nice guy and knows what he is talking about. I have never take a mass com. class before I really enjoyed. You do need to write a lot for this class. But overall it was a fun class, and the prof is very understanding and super cool. I would def. take another class with him

Wells is fantastic.  He is passionate about his subject and conveys his lectures in a modern way.  He is funny,extremely responsive and caring toward his students. A lot of work, but it is not too difficult. Tests are fair.  TA determines your grade.

Awesome class, awesome professor!  Quite a lot of work (3 tests, 3 essays, a speech, and other assignments) but that should be expected of a CommB course.  For all of the work though, it was a pretty easy class.  Material is interesting and Wells made it fun and relevant.  Highly recommend Bill Hogue as your TA, too!

Wells did a good job with this course, it's a lot of material and he moved pretty quickly sometimes and was occasionally hard to follow along with (his lectures were somewhat organized at times). But otherwise he tried to be fun and the work wasn't too bad. A lot of reading but the material is interesting. Tests are straight off study guide
Great prof. Clear, helpful, and interesting. Lectures should be be attended, as the tests are basically lecture based.
Really cool prof, lectures went by quickly and were full of information so not a good idea to skip often. Tests were easy, three 4-page papers. Overall good class!

There's no textbook for this class. It's all articles posted on Learn@UW. The class is also discussion based with minimal lecturing from the professor. It makes it a lot more interesting than a regular lecture class. Four 600 word discussion papers, one 10 page midterm paper and one final group project
